articles.headline: Government Takes Legal Action Over Phone Spam
articles.snippet: In eight federal civil cases, the Federal Trade Commission named 29 individuals, most of whom worked for companies that were hired to send the unsolicited text messages.
articles.abstract: In eight federal civil cases, the Federal Trade Commission named 29 individuals, most of whom worked for companies that were hired to send the unsolicited text messages.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Trade Commission said on Thursday that it had recently filed eight lawsuits in federal courts around the country against companies it accused of ordering or engineering the sending of hundreds of millions of spam text messages to mobile phone users.

articles.headline: A Senator’s Stand on Drones Scrambles Partisan Lines
articles.snippet: Senator Rand Paul’s filibuster won praise from the Tea Party movement and civil-liberties-minded liberals, but two prominent fellow Republicans accused him of scaremongering.
articles.abstract: Senator Rand Paul’s filibuster won praise from the Tea Party movement and civil-liberties-minded liberals, but two prominent fellow Republicans accused him of scaremongering.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Rand Paul’s intention was to highlight his misgivings about how drones are used. He ended up enmeshing his fellow Republicans in a broader debate over national security that scrambled the politics of left and right.
articles.byline: By Richard W. Stevenson and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: At an Annual Tech Show, It’s Hardware’s Turn in the Spotlight
articles.snippet: Thanks to 3-D printers and online sources of financing, the South by Southwest conference features an unusual number of new devices this year.
articles.abstract: Thanks to 3-D printers and online sources of financing, the South by Southwest conference features an unusual number of new devices this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Each year, thousands of tech enthusiasts flock to South by Southwest, the technology, music and film conference here, hoping to be among the first to find the next big thing in social networking and mobile apps.

articles.headline: Latinos Gain Political Muscle, and Fund-Raisers Show How
articles.snippet: A new generation of Latino leaders — highly educated, sophisticated and rich — is tapping into Hispanics as a fund-raising pool to influence elections and policy.
articles.abstract: A new generation of Latino leaders — highly educated, sophisticated and rich — is tapping into Hispanics as a fund-raising pool to influence elections and policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — On a wall in his sun-drenched, art-filled Tudor home, Henry R. Muñoz III displays a memento of his childhood: a framed protest sign proclaiming, “Texas needs $1.25 an hour minimum wage.” He carried it when he was 6 years old while riding a burro during a farm workers’ march alongside his father, a labor organizer, and the Mexican-American activist Cesar Chavez.

articles.headline: Bin Laden Relative With Qaeda Past to Have New York Trial
articles.snippet: A son-in-law of Osama bin Laden who once served as a spokesman for Al Qaeda will appear in court Friday to face terrorism charges that could bring a life sentence.
articles.abstract: A son-in-law of Osama bin Laden who once served as a spokesman for Al Qaeda will appear in court Friday to face terrorism charges that could bring a life sentence.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Weeks after he was first arrested in Turkey, a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden who once served as a spokesman for Al Qaeda will appear in a New York courtroom on Friday to face terrorism charges that could result in life imprisonment.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and William K. Rashbaum

articles.headline: Banks Pass Fed’s Tests; Critics Say It Was Easy
articles.snippet: The results of so-called stress tests on Thursday indicate that most banks would survive a severe recession and a crash in the markets, paving the way for banks to increase their dividends and buy back shares.
articles.abstract: The results of so-called stress tests on Thursday indicate that most banks would survive a severe recession and a crash in the markets, paving the way for banks to increase their dividends and buy back shares.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Regulators Get Latitude in the Split of MBIA
articles.snippet: A court action brought against MBIA said it had made inaccurate regulatory filings before it split up. The case’s dismissal allows the insurer to pursue its strategy for corporate survival.
articles.abstract: A court action brought against MBIA said it had made inaccurate regulatory filings before it split up. The case’s dismissal allows the insurer to pursue its strategy for corporate survival.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some people are inherently more deserving of sympathy than others.

articles.headline: Imagining a Swap Meet for E-Books and Music
articles.snippet: The prospect of online stores that sell used e-books and digital music has heartened consumer advocates, but publishers and artists are worried.
articles.abstract: The prospect of online stores that sell used e-books and digital music has heartened consumer advocates, but publishers and artists are worried.
articles.lead_paragraph: The paperback of “Fifty Shades of Grey” is exactly like the digital version except for this: If you hate the paperback, you can give it away or resell it. If you hate the e-book, you’re stuck with it.

articles.headline: Leader of Vote Count in Kenya Faces U.S. With Tough Choices
articles.snippet: The Obama administration has signaled its disfavor for Uhuru Kenyatta, accused of war crimes, who was ahead in presidential balloting. But rejecting him could harm ties to a vital ally.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration has signaled its disfavor for Uhuru Kenyatta, accused of war crimes, who was ahead in presidential balloting. But rejecting him could harm ties to a vital ally.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — He has been charged with heinous crimes, accused of using a vast fortune to bankroll death squads that slaughtered women and children. His running mate also faces charges of crimes against humanity, and as Kenya’s election drew closer, the Obama administration’s top official for Africa issued a thinly veiled warning during a conference call about the vote, saying that Kenyans are, of course, free to pick their own leaders but that “choices have consequences.”

articles.headline: In a Spinoff of Time Inc., Evolution Is Complete
articles.snippet: With the spinoff of Time Inc., Time Warner has become an example of the media industry’s shift away from rapid acquisition and growth.
articles.abstract: With the spinoff of Time Inc., Time Warner has become an example of the media industry’s shift away from rapid acquisition and growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: The sprawling media conglomerate that Steven J. Ross joined together, Jeffrey L. Bewkes has put asunder.

articles.headline: Unemployment at 4-Year Low as U.S. Hiring Gains Steam
articles.snippet: The joblessness rate sank to 7.7 percent as 236,000 positions were added across a broad range of sectors, but analysts warned that federal budget cuts could slow the recovery.
articles.abstract: The joblessness rate sank to 7.7 percent as 236,000 positions were added across a broad range of sectors, but analysts warned that federal budget cuts could slow the recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: The economy picked up speed in February, creating jobs at a pace that would substantially lower the unemployment rate. But Washington could put a stop to that.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Binyamin Appelbaum

articles.headline: Reality TV for the Red Planet
articles.snippet: A Dutch entrepreneur's financial plan for a colony on Mars is based on selling the television rights to cover the project every step of the way.
articles.abstract: A Dutch entrepreneur's financial plan for a colony on Mars is based on selling the television rights to cover the project every step of the way.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — As Wernher von Braun, the rocket scientist, used to say, the most overwhelming obstacle to exploring the cosmos isn’t gravity. It’s the paperwork.
